title: David's Case of Acute Chest and Throat Pain
clinical_history: David is a 42-year-old accountant who presented with sudden onset of left-sided chest and anterior throat pain while eating dinner three days ago. The pain was sharp and constricting, radiating from the upper chest to the lower aspect of his throat. He noted associated difficulty swallowing and mild shortness of breath, but no syncope or nausea. He denied any prior history of cardiac or respiratory issues. The pain is described as constant with intermittent spikes, especially on swallowing solids or taking a deep breath. No heartburn reported. At rest, the pain slightly eases but does not fully resolve. David reports the pain disrupted his sleep the first night but now mostly flares with movement or meals.

nprs.affected_area: left anterior chest (pectoralis major, intercostal muscles 2ndâ€“4th ribs)

aggrevating_factors: Swallowing solids, deep inspiration, coughing, rapid trunk rotation, and speaking at length aggravate the pain significantly.
picture: [insert image highlighting left pectoral region and anterior neck/throat]
easing_factors: Resting with head elevated, sipping cool fluids, and supportive gentle pressure to the chest reduce discomfort. Soft foods are easier to swallow.
past_history: No previous chest or neck pain. Non-smoker, minimal alcohol use. No recent trauma.
medical_history: History of mild allergic rhinitis; no known cardiac, gastroesophageal, or neuromuscular conditions.
medications: Occasional use of loratadine for allergies. Currently taking acetaminophen 650mg every 6 hours for pain (partial relief).
personal_history: Sedentary occupation, moderate stress related to work deadlines. Married, no children. Regularly exercises by walking three times a week.
imaging: Chest X-ray and soft tissue neck X-ray revealed no acute pathology. Awaiting further diagnostic workup (ENT and gastroenterology referrals).
